content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <metadata>  <idinfo>   <citation>    <citeinfo>     <origin>Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative</origin>     <pubdate>20120828</pubdate>     <title>Threatened Eider Geodatabase, Incidental Observation Attributes. Arctic LCC (2012).</title>     <geoform>tabular digital data</geoform>     <pubinfo>      <pubplace>Fairbanks, AK</pubplace>      <publish>Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative</publish>     </pubinfo>     <othercit>Users are strongly encouraged to cite original data sources whenever they extract information from the larger dataset for specific analysis.</othercit>     <onlink>http://arcticlcc.org/products/</onlink>    </citeinfo>   </citation>   <descript>    <abstract>This table contains information related to incidental observations of threatened eiders and is one component of the Threatened Eider Geodatabase. This database is intended to be a qualitative "first look" at where these two species of eider have been recorded and where surveys have been conducted. This spatial dataset is intended for general planning and mapping purposes rather than for deriving density estimates.The geodatabase is comprised of two feature classes (SPEI_STEI_Observations and Survey_Polys) and two tables (Eider_Incidental_attributes and Eider_Reference_Information).</abstract>    <purpose>The Arctic LCC created the Threatened Eider Geodatabase to serve as a primary repository for threatened eider distribution information.  his database is intended to be a qualitative "first look" at where these two species of eider have been recorded and where surveys have been conducted.  This dataset is intended for general planning and mapping purposes, it should NOT be used for deriving density estimates.  Users are reminded that these data do not represent all locations within the geographic scope of this database that may be occupied by threatened eiders.</purpose>    <supplinf>Observations of eiders are considered to have been derived from a survey if both of the following conditions are met 1) there was a search area with reasonably well-defined boundaries, and 2) eiders were among the taxa specifically targeted by the survey.  All observations of eiders that do not meet these criteria are treated as incidental observations - these could include observations contributed by persons engaged in activities other than wildlife surveys, observations obtained during the course of biological survey work targeted at another species such as caribou, and historical observations from the literature.  Incidental observations are assigned the non-unique value Incidental  in the SURVEY_ID field and are related to the Eider_Incidental_Attributes table via a unique value in the Incd_ID field.</supplinf>   </descript>   <timeperd>    <timeinfo>     <rngdates>      <begdate>1991</begdate>      <enddate>2010</enddate>     </rngdates>    </timeinfo>    <current>ground condition</current>   </timeperd>   <status>    <progress>Complete</progress>    <update>As needed</update>   </status>   <spdom>    <bounding>     <westbc>-169</westbc>     <eastbc>-135.0</eastbc>     <northbc>74.7</northbc>     <southbc>66.5</southbc>    </bounding>   </spdom>   <keywords>    <theme>     <themekt>ISO 19115 Topic Category</themekt>     <themekey>biota</themekey>    </theme>    <theme>     <themekt>User</themekt>     <themekey>eider</themekey>     <themekey>spectacled eiders</themekey>     <themekey>Steller's eider</themekey>     <themekey>eider observations</themekey>     <themekey>survey</themekey>    </theme>    <place>     <placekt>None</placekt>     <placekey>Alaska</placekey>    </place>   </keywords>   <accconst>None.</accconst>   <useconst>Neither the Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative or contributors to this dataset shall be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.  In an effort to provide the most comprehensive overview possible, we have incorporated many data sources, representing many different survey methods. It is not possible to apply a uniform quantification of survey effort across this wide variety of data sets because not all of the eider observations are associated with a clearly defined survey area. Therefore, the user should avoid aggregating data from multiple sources to derive density estimates. When interpreting these data, users are reminded to consider that detectability of eiders is a function of many variables, including differences in species, habitat, time-of-year, weather conditions, and survey techniques. Inherent in any data set used to develop graphical representations, are limitations of accuracy as determined by, among others, the source, scale and resolution of the data.</useconst>   <ptcontac>    <cntinfo>     <cntorgp>      <cntorg>Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative</cntorg>     </cntorgp>     <cntpos>Geospatial Specialist</cntpos>     <cntaddr>      <addrtype>mailing and physical address</addrtype>      <address>101 12th Ave.</address>      <city>Fairbanks</city>      <state>Alaska</state>      <postal>99701</postal>     </cntaddr>     <cntvoice>907 456 0327</cntvoice>     <cntemail>data@arcticlcc.org</cntemail>     <cntinst>Contact by phone or email.</cntinst>    </cntinfo>   </ptcontac>   <datacred>Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative</datacred>   <secinfo>    <secsys>FIPS Pub 199</secsys>    <secclass>No Confidentiality</secclass>    <sechandl>Standard Technical Controls</sechandl>   </secinfo>   <native>Microsoft Windows 7; ESRI ArcGIS 10</native>  </idinfo>  <dataqual>   <logic>Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative (Arctic LCC) staff and contractors have compiled this dataset to the best of their abilities using the resources available to them.  Although the data have been gathered by sources believed to be reliable, Arctic LCC neither verifies nor guarantees the accuracy, reliability, or completeness of these data.   If you find any errors or omissions, we encourage you to report them to the Arctic LCC data custodian (data@arcticlcc.org).</logic>   <complete>Users are reminded that these data do not represent all locations within the geographic scope of this database that may be occupied by threatened eiders.</complete>   <lineage>    <procstep>     <procdesc>Data were collected from different sources and subsequently processed (reformatted) so that they could be aggregated and distributed.</procdesc>     <procdate>20120401</procdate>     <proccont>      <cntinfo>       <cntorgp>        <cntorg>Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative</cntorg>       </cntorgp>       <cntpos>Geospatial Specialists</cntpos>       <cntaddr>        <addrtype>mailing and physical address</addrtype>        <address>101 12th Ave</address>        <city>Fairbanks</city>        <state>Alaska</state>        <postal>99701</postal>        <country>USA</country>       </cntaddr>       <cntvoice>907 456 0327</cntvoice>       <cntemail>data@arcticlcc.org</cntemail>       <hours>7:30 am to 4:30 pm</hours>       <cntinst>Contact by phone or email.</cntinst>      </cntinfo>     </proccont>    </procstep>   </lineage>  </dataqual>  <eainfo>   <detailed>    <enttyp>     <enttypl>Eider_Incidental_Attributes</enttypl>     <enttypd>This table contains information related to incidental observations of threatened eiders.</enttypd>     <enttypds>Arctic LCC</enttypds>    </enttyp>    <attr>     <attrlabl>OBJECTID</attrlabl>     <attrdef>Internal feature number.</attrdef>     <attrdefs>Arctic LCC</attrdefs>     <attrdomv>      <udom>Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.</udom>     </attrdomv>    </attr>    <attr>     <attrlabl>Incd_ID</attrlabl>     <attrdef>Required.  Unique identifier for incidental observations.  Any observation that occurs outside of surveys that targeted eiders will be assigned an incidental ID (Incd_ID).  The \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdIncd_ID\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd will be a combination of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdIncd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd underscore year (YYYY) underscore incidental # (sequential).  Examples:  Incd_2004_999, Incd_2005_001, and Incd_2005_2005.</attrdef>     <attrdefs>Arctic LCC</attrdefs>     <attrdomv>      <udom>Unique ID for each observation</udom>     </attrdomv>    </attr>    <attr>     <attrlabl>Location</attrlabl>     <attrdef>General description of where the observation occurred.  For example, Barrow Triangle, Alpine, Prudhoe Bay.</attrdef>     <attrdefs>Arctic LCC</attrdefs>     <attrdomv>      <udom>General description of location where an individual or group was seen</udom>     </attrdomv>    </attr>    <attr>     <attrlabl>Type</attrlabl>     <attrdef>Describes the type: aerial or ground</attrdef>     <attrdefs>Arctic LCC</attrdefs>     <attrdomv>      <edom>       <edomv>aerial</edomv>       <edomvd>Observation made from the air</edomvd>       <edomvds>Arctic LCC</edomvds>      </edom>      <edom>       <edomv>ground</edomv>       <edomvd>Observation made from the ground</edomvd>       <edomvds>Arctic LCC</edomvds>      </edom>     </attrdomv>    </attr>    <attr>     <attrlabl>Platform</attrlabl>     <attrdef>Describes the platform used: fixed-wing, helicopter, non-motorized, motorized.</attrdef>     <attrdefs>Arctic LCC</attrdefs>     <attrdomv>      <edom>       <edomv>fixed-wing</edomv>       <edomvd>Observation made from fixed-wing aircraft</edomvd>       <edomvds>Arctic LCC</edomvds>      </edom>      <edom>       <edomv>helicopter</edomv>       <edomvd>Observation made from a helicopter</edomvd>       <edomvds>Arctic LCC</edomvds>      </edom>      <edom>       <edomv>non-motorized</edomv>       <edomvd>Observation made from the ground using non-motorized transportation</edomvd>       <edomvds>Arctic LCC</edomvds>      </edom>      <edom>       <edomv>motorized</edomv>       <edomvd>Observation made from the ground using motorized transportation</edomvd>       <edomvds>Arctic LCC</edomvds>      </edom>     </attrdomv>    </attr>    <attr>     <attrlabl>Map_Mthd</attrlabl>     <attrdef>Method used to map the observation area.  Classified as topo, aerial photo, satellite image, GPS, or a combination of these.</attrdef>     <attrdefs>Arctic LCC</attrdefs>     <attrdomv>      <udom>Method used to map observation</udom>     </attrdomv>    </attr>    <attr>     <attrlabl>Error_Ind</attrlabl>     <attrdef>Indicator of accuracy.  May be scale of map or photo (example; 1:250,000, 1:63,360, 1"=500') or precision of GPS coordinates (example; averaged, instantaneous, averaged from a distance, averaged on-top the point, and instantaneous on-top the point).</attrdef>     <attrdefs>Arctic LCC</attrdefs>     <attrdomv>      <udom>Indicator of accuracy.</udom>     </attrdomv>    </attr>    <attr>     <attrlabl>Ref_ID</attrlabl>     <attrdef>Identifies the record, within the Eider_References_Information table that is associated with an incidental observation.</attrdef>     <attrdefs>Arctic LCC</attrdefs>     <attrdomv>      <udom>Unique whole number</udom>     </attrdomv>    </attr>    <attr>     <attrlabl>Reference</attrlabl>     <attrdef>Name of the reference where information about the observation can be found.</attrdef>     <attrdefs>Arctic LCC</attrdefs>     <attrdomv>      <udom>Name of reference.</udom>     </attrdomv>    </attr>    <attr>     <attrlabl>Contact</attrlabl>     <attrdef>Point of contact for the observation.</attrdef>     <attrdefs>Arctic LCC</attrdefs>     <attrdomv>      <udom>Name of contact.</udom>     </attrdomv>    </attr>    <attr>     <attrlabl>Email</attrlabl>     <attrdef>Email address for point of contact.</attrdef>     <attrdefs>Arctic LCC</attrdefs>     <attrdomv>      <udom>Email address of contact.</udom>     </attrdomv>
